content.text: Bash tail Command - Display Last Part of Files
Using the tail Command
The tail command is used to display the last part of files.
content.html: The tail command is used to display the last part of files.

content.text: It's particularly useful for viewing the end of log files or any file that is being updated in real-time.
content.html: It's particularly useful for viewing the end of log files or any file that is being updated in real-time.

content.text: Syntax
The basic syntax of the tail command is:
content.html: The basic syntax of the tail command is:

content.code_html: tail [OPTION]... [FILE]...

content.code:
tail
logfile.txt
line 91
line 92
line 93
line 94
line 95
line 96
line 97
line 98
line 99
line 100
content.code_html:
tail logfile.txt
line 91
line 92
line 93
line 94
line 95
line 96
line 97
line 98
line 99
line 100

content.text: Options
The tail command has several options to customize its behavior:
content.html: The tail command has several options to customize its behavior:

content.text: Option: -n [number]
The -n option allows you to specify the number of lines to display from the end of the file.
content.html: The -n option allows you to specify the number of lines to display from the end of the file.

content.text: By default, tail shows the last 10 lines.
content.html: By default, tail shows the last 10 lines.

content.code:
tail
-n
5
logfile.txt
line 96
line 97
line 98
line 99
line 100
content.code_html:
tail -n 5 logfile.txt
line 96
line 97
line 98
line 99
line 100

content.text: Option: -f
The -f option is used to follow a file as it grows, which is particularly useful for monitoring log files in real-time.
content.html: The -f option is used to follow a file as it grows, which is particularly useful for monitoring log files in real-time.

content.code:
tail
-f logfile.txt
line 91
line 92
line 93
line 94
line 95
line 96
line 97
line 98
line 99
line 100
line 101
content.code_html:
tail -f logfile.txt
line 91
line 92
line 93
line 94
line 95
line 96
line 97
line 98
line 99
line 100
line 101

content.text: Option: -c [number]
The -c option allows you to display the last [number] bytes of a file instead of lines.
content.html: The -c option allows you to display the last [number] bytes of a file instead of lines.

content.code_html:
tail -c 20 logfile.txt

end of logfile.txt

content.text: Option: --pid=[pid]
The --pid option terminates tailing after the process with the given PID dies. This is useful for stopping the tail operation when a related process ends.
content.html: The --pid option terminates tailing after the process with the given PID dies. This is useful for stopping the tail operation when a related process ends.

content.code_html:
tail -f --pid=1234 logfile.txt
line 91
line 92
line 93
...

content.text: Option: --retry
The --retry option makes tail keep trying to open a file even if it is inaccessible. This is useful for files that may be temporarily unavailable.
content.html: The --retry option makes tail keep trying to open a file even if it is inaccessible. This is useful for files that may be temporarily unavailable.

content.code:
tail
--retry -f logfile.txt
tail: cannot
open

'logfile.txt'

for
reading: No such
file
or directory
line
91

line
92

line
93


..
.
content.code_html:
tail --retry -f logfile.txt
tail: cannot open 'logfile.txt' for reading: No such file or directory
line 91
line 92
line 93
...
